[h1] Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes - Review[/h1]

Well, that was a surprise. I completely didn't expect this game to look like that. It is not Counter-Strike that everybody knows. It's a proper single-player campaign!
The storyline doesn't really exist - each missions is a separate scenario, which pretty much looks the same in each level: you play as a counter-terrorist, go in somewhere, kill the bad guys, maybe defuse a bomb at the end or rescue some hostages. Simple, yet fun. Unfortunately, the visual layer got old really quickly - the game is quite ugly. In terms of audio, it's alright. There is a lot of funny dialogue between "not-the-smartest" terrorists. Deleted Scenes is also filled with a a lot of easter eggs, so while being generally mature, it also makes the player laugh.

At the end of the day, I enjoyed those 9 hours I spent with CSCZDS (lol). It was a great experience and a nice stepping stone from the original formula of Counter-Strike.

This game has lots of points. Sometimes i just wanted to quit and play something else, others i was truly enjoying the gameplay.
The thing about it is it takes itself way too seriously. The missions are pretty straight forward, just keep moving onwards and killing enemies until you finish, with rare occasions of having to use your brain. The stealth missions, in the other way are EXTREMELY boring and frustrating, since it's just waiting and walking, with the enemies having eagle vision on you, sometimes seeing you through walls even.
The good points are for example when it let itself go and stop trying to be Counter Strike, and approximating more to a Half Life formula, which was pretty well done in mission 12, the skyscraper.
The game doesn't really have a story, it is just defending the world from terrorists, which is ok, and that is something you should know before buying.
Conclusion: it can be a nice fun for somebody who wants to play a cod-like game with a CS feeling, but the CS formula just fits way better when we are talking about Competitive multiplayer shooters.

Old School Counter Strike. Even for the date of release the graphics were....terrible. We had Half Life 2, Halo 2, COD 1 in the same year, and by far, surpassed the graphics in this game. However the old graphics can serve as an advantage,  as even the most potato-y of PC/Laptops can run this no problem. I tried running this on a 15 year old PC with 4 GB of Ram, and about 215 MB of V-Ram, and it ran smoothly. If you can get passed the graphical limitations of the game, then you will find an enjoyable experience. This game serves as the most tactical Counter Strike yet, with a good campaign experience. Outside of graphics, the story and setting is immersive, detailed, and most importantly fun. The unconnected and non-linear story allows for a variety of locations in the world.

I would highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a cheap, simple shooter, that can run on the most crummiest of systems.

It's an ok side gig in the series, people behind CZ definitely were passionate about what they were making, not only renewing the og CS, but also making a single player campaign. Some levels shine through with some interesting ideas and execution, however there are some bugs and jank.

Basically it takes the CS mechanics and all, adds some special equipment, and slaps it onto an half-life like missions. Naturally it doesn't translate super well, recoil, reload times and movement speed are all clearly not the best fit for that kind of game. It is playable of course, and not all that terrible, yet it feels a little off.
It has a handful of very weird things about it, often it's not super clear where you need to go, you sometimes have to sneak around, you get ambushes with rocket launcher guys, sometimes it throws a handful of enemies at you, and each time they hit you, you get the screen turning effect just like normal CS.
I also had a game breaking bug at the weeb level, which is a shame as that one was probably the most interesting, since it was in actual city streets with civilians around.

If you bought the cs pack, it might be worth a shot, keep in mind it's nothing phenomenal, and if you pay attention to the story, you might actually have less fun, seeing how many god damn super special agent infiltrator movie tropes they crammed in (cmon lone wolf, defuse the nuke XDDD). It's quite a basic shooter all in all, but a neat little addition nonetheless.

[b]Intro[/b]
Note: This is a review of the Deleted Scenes campaign only. The content/replayibility score does take in other modes however.

[b]The Great:[/b]
++N/A

[b]The Good:[/b]
+Sound design's actually somewhat decent with some really punchy weapon effects and half-decent environmental effects
+There's something oddly enjoyable about Gold Source's engine despite its annoying quirks. I honestly can't put my finger on it, but I'm sure plenty of people can relate.
+There's some bonus levels outside of the campaign
+The combat isn't totally without its' merits

[b]The Okay/Not Too Big of a Deal:[/b]
+-The devs actually managed to do some impressive things with the engine. Animating dead bodies to look like true ragdoll as in other games for one, and animating crumpling paper and crushing boxes for some more. I don't know how they managed to do some of it on the engine, but it actually does a good job of mimicking
real physics. It absolutely doesn't save this game's presentation, though.
-+The voice acting isn't the worst thing in the world but it's certainly not good, and the phony accents don't help

[b]The Bad:[/b]
-If you're below 25 health, all you can really do is pray to the RNG gods that both the enemy will decide to miss you and that your weapons will be accurate, which aren't often the case. So sometimes you'll go around a corner and die over and over until you get lucky and the enemies decide to miss and your bullets
decide to hit where you're aiming.
-Hit detection is awful, and I know I'm not mistaking it for inaccurate weaponry
-Reload animations are annoyingly long
-Movement is as slippery as Half-Life's, but much slower. Given how many thin ledges and platforming is required from you, I have to wonder who thought giving the character roller-skates was a good idea.
-The campaign is very short. Under 4 hours even on Hard. There are some bonus maps, however.
-Enemy placement is BS sometimes, but especially on the last level
-There is no story. There are settings and objectives for each level, but they're totally self-contained.
-It's barely a challenge for at least half the game, but then the enemy placements get more annoying and it starts kicking your butt some more
-Music's forgettable
-The stealth sections work about as well as you'd expect on this engine. Thankfully, they're rare and cheese-able.

[b]The Horrible:[/b]
--This game came out in 2004... two thousand and fucking four. Yet, it barely looks better than the original Half-Life, which ALREADY looked out of date 6 years ago! To compare this game visually to Half-Life 2, Doom 3, Thief Deadly Shadows, or, you know, ANY game released in 2004, is like comparing the U.S. healthcare
to any other first-world country -- it's nothing but a laughing stock.
--Counter-Strike's trademark nonsensical, ridiculous recoil system made playing this more and more annoying. It's often up to RNG as to whether you'll actually hit anything thanks to random weapon spread mixed with strong recoil. Sometimes you can get two easy headshots without a problem, and sometimes you'll miss
even with your crosshair clearly right on their head and even shots point blank at their body. It's just absurd.
--Incredibly repetitive. Shoot similar types of braindead enemies over and over while planting a bomb or pulling out a gadget every now and then.

Sound: 5.5/10
Graphics: 2/10
Gameplay: 4/10
Content/Replayability: 8/10
Overall: 4.5/10

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Not a dreadful experience, but I can't recommend it. Good for a nostalgia trip if you played this at the time, or just to kill a few hours, but that's about it. I'm sure you have better things to do and games to waste your life on. I don't, that's why I bothered to finish it.

Historical context: this game was in development for almost 3 years, long overdue and long over-schedule. It was touched by a total 5 different development studios (Rogue Entertainment, Valve, Gearbox, Ritual, Turtle Rock) and had at least 3 distinct development resets. Deleted Scenes is Ritual's singleplayer campaign, which is best described as Counter-Strike meets Half-Life by way of Medal of Honor/Call of Duty. It's a mission-based CS game with scripted, linear levels but it plays pretty well and has great use of scripting to keep the action constantly going.

The only issue is that when Valve modified the game before finally releasing it in March 2004, like altering the mission structure and remove 6 missions from the game. [h1] Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes [/h1]

[b] A Very Sub-par, Single-player Focused Counter-Strike [/b]

[b] Counter Strike: Condition Zero [/b] sounded somewhat appealing to me on paper - a single-player focused story that could weave a tale within the CS universe. What I encountered instead was a boring, repetitive story mode with predictable mission structure and brainless enemy AI.

The campaign, from what I played, is very disappointing. There doesn't seem to be any coherent plot, so you're just running around doing single-player missions for no reason at all. The diversity of tactics that fuel CS gameplay is so watered down that it frankly doesn't even exist. It plays like a poor version of an original "Call of Duty" title, but at least in those games you have some sort of consistent mission and theme. Here, its essentially a mission pack that proves itself to be fairly basic, boring, and asinine.

There is very little character design, and the levels are appear muddy and washed out. There are cliche hostage rescue missions, escort mission, and "sneak in unnoticed and take everyone out" type missions. The game is flavorless - it functions, but there is no soul behind it.

The audio is at least pretty good, even despite the other technical limitations. With more polish and work put into this title, it really could have served as a stand-out, smash-hit for Ritual, Turtle Rock, and Valve, but alas it was squandered and remains as a very forgettable CS experience. In the end, I would [b] Not Recommend [/b] playing [b] Counter-Strike: Condition Zero [/b] unless you are a very big CS fan and are desperate for some old-school content.

[h2] Final Verdict: 4/10 (Below Average) [/h2]

Released less than a year before Valve introduced the world to the Source engine with the release of Half-Life 2, Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes is something of a swan song to the GoldSrc engine that powered the first Half-Life game and its derivative mods/campaigns.

If Half-Life offered gamers the first cinematic FPS experience in history, CS:CZ DS is something like the first half-hour action anthology television series FPS. Across 18 unconnected single-player episodes, players take on the role of various counter-terrorist agencies across the globe and complete mission objectives including hostage rescue, sabotage, and killing every terrorist in sight. The graphics, animation, and voice acting are all great for their time and offer a fine dose of nostalgia for older gamers.

Those who have played any of the mainline Counter-Strike games will find few similarities in CS:CZ DS's gameplay (aside from some cosmetic and thematic similarities). The team coordination and tense showdowns of CS have been replaced by standard single-player FPS mechanics, and the level design is highly (perhaps excessively) linear.

Still, CS:CZ DS is very much worth playing. The gameplay is varied and exciting, the scripted events are spectacular (in the Half-Life mold), and the overall production values are exactly what you would expect from Valve.

Counter-Strike Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes is a breath of fresh air to play, even now. A classic game, it can be easily mistaken as one of those games that fill your library but goes untouched, which is a big mistake. This game was mostly overlooked during the time of its release and neglected as nobody was ready for a Counter-Strike "story mode" game. And who can blame the playerbase, at a time when a multiplayer Counter-Strike was at the height of its popularity with the rise of ESports and thousands of dollars in tournaments. But, like many movies that flop and turn into cult classic later in their time, Condition Zero deleted scenes by Ritual Entertainment is an amazing change, it's like playing Half-life but with Counter-Strike flowing through it, like some strange lovechild of the two franchises. I would argue this game is the original Call of Duty, offering the same thing from an equally huge blockbuster title. I would definitely recommend this game if you like CS 1.6 as it brings the original Counter-Strike into story mode form with thrilling fast paced 80s action style missions.

For what it is, I think it's a great little game to grind out on a rainy weekend when you have nothing else to do. 

The storyline of the game isn't really the most engaging or interesting, it's kind of your standard 'Here's a set of missions leading up to this big momentous event that you need to carry out.' I won't spoil it, but I would personally go into the game to see the progress of CS, the FPS genre and Valve in general. One thing I will say, is that the level design for the game is quite impressive for the time. The immersion of the game is something that I really enjoyed. Some levels make you feel like you're in Saving Private Ryan, others like you're in Indiana Jones, and others like building scene towards the end from The Matrix. The missions that you have to play suit different playstyles quite well too. If you're someone who goes in all-guns-blazing like Rambo, you can do that, but you'll have to rely on your aim and reaction times being quite good. You can play it slow too, peeking corners carefully, and clearing out rooms as though you were destined for a SWAT team. Or if utility is more your thing, then you can take advantage of smokes, flashes, molotovs, and grenades too. As well, some levels have a puzzle-like element to them, where you have to find a way to progress through the stage, whether that's looking for a vent that you have to crawl through, finding a ladder disguised as a pipe, or a specific item that helps you blast open a door. I will admit (shamefully) there were some times where I did have to look at a walkthrough, but I'm a little impatient, and had I spent an extra 5 minutes, I probably would've been fine. Gameplay is identical to that of CS:CZ, with graphics and performance being the same.

No, it's not the best game that Valve has ever made, but I would take the game as more of a learning experience. A product of its time. Yes, the graphics look VERY dated compared to today, and the level design doesn't compare to what we have now, but you have see the game from the eyes of someone from 2004, and you will see a glimpse of appreciation for where we are today. Give the game a try, don't take it too seriously, have fun.

[h1] CS: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes Review [/h1]

CSCZ: DS is probably the only story-based entry in the entirety of the Counter-Strike games, and the singleplayer manages to actually be fairly good. Running on the GoldSrc engine of Half-Life and Counter-Strike 1.6, the game has a bunch of story-oriented missions where you can go around killing terrorists and rescuing hostages in many locations. 

The training area is surprisingly well made also, but I feel that there were a few areas that were a bit buggy at times, and that might just be because it's on a 1997/98 game engine of all things. 

CSCZ DS also has little health/medical cabinets to replace the health chargers that you could find throughout HL1 (if you've played that), and suit charge is replaced with basic ballistic armour. 

The gunplay is pretty good in most of the levels (at least the ones that I have played for myself), but there are a few places where it gets a bit annoying, especially if you lack the appropriate equipment (in one level, I think it was Alamo, there can be a terrorist who continuously throws grenades down the stairs). The melee is also pretty mediocre, especially since this is, once again, a GoldSrc game. That makes the melee more like this: Hit, get to cover, hit, get to cover, repeat until enemy is dead.

Overall, I recommend it if you want a Counter-Strike story mode. It's obviously not up to the graphics or physics standards of CS:GO or CSS, but it mostly makes up for it in the gameplay department.
